chapter: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 1: Principal cells and intercalated cells are present in which part of the nephron?

options.a: Distal collecting tubule and collecting duct
options.c: Proximal collecting tubule and loop of Henle
options.d: Loop of Henle and distal collecting tubule

questions.explanation:
Principal cells and intercalated cells are present in the distal collecting tubule and collecting duct. P cell 
I cell Functi 
ons Na+reabsorptionWater reabs 
orptionK secretion Type A-H+secretion, HCO3 r 
eabsorption in acidosis.Type 
B-HCO3 secretion, acid reab 
sorption in alkalosis. 632 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Principal cells are the primary sites of action of potassium-sparing diuretics.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 2: How does DCT differ from PCT?

options.b: Carbonic anhydrase in its luminal membrane
options.d: No Na+ - K+ ATPase in its basolateral membrane

questions.explanation:
DCT has 'tight' tight junctions, while PCT has 'leaky' tight junctions. The 'tight' tight junctions can maintain the high electrochemical gradients produced by active 
transcellular transport. This configuration is used to produce either highly concentrated or diluted 
secretions, as in the distal nephron. Hence, it can produce urine with osmolarity severalfold 
higher or lower than plasma. In contrast, epithelia with 'leaky' tight junctions move large amounts of isosmotic fluids. A good 
example is a transport in PCT. Na+- K- ATPase is present throughout most parts of the nephron. PCT 
DCT Brush border present in the a 
pical membrane No brush border Cytoplasmic carbonic anhydr 
ase (type 2 & type 4) present Cytoplasmic carbonic anhydr 
ase (type 2 only) Has ‘leaky’ tight junctions 
Has ‘tight’ tight junctions No paracellular transport Paracellular transport is poss 
ible via leaky tight junctions
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 3: In comparison to cortical nephron, juxtamedullary nephron
questions.explanation:
633 
Sold by @itachibot In comparison to cortical nephrons, juxtamedullary nephrons are characterized by a long loop of 
Henle that descends deep into the inner medulla. It is essential for the concentration of urine.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.explanation:
Kidneys receive approximately 20 to 25% of the cardiac output, which is approximately 1000 mL 
per minute. Region

questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 5: What is the normal resting GFR?
questions.explanation:
The GFR in a healthy adult of average size is approximately 125 mL/min. Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is the volume of fluid filtered from the renal 
glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's capsule per unit time. The GFR is determined by 634 
Sold by @itachibot • Sum of the hydrostatic and colloid osmotic forces across the glomerular membrane, which gives 
the net filtration pressure • Glomerular Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient) Mathematically, it can be expressed as follows: GFR= Kf [ forces favoring filtration- forces opposing filteration] GFR= Kf [PG + B -PB- G] Forces Favoring Filtration PG: Glomerular hydrostatic pressure B: Bowman’s capsule oncotic pressure Forces Opposing Filtration PB: Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure G: Glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 6: What is the renal blood flow in a resting adult?
questions.explanation:
In a resting adult, the kidneys receive 1.2–1.3 L of blood per minute or just under 25% of the 
cardiac output. Among the given options, 1-1.5 L/min is the closest range. Renal blood flow is determined by the pressure gradient across the renal vasculature (the 
difference between the renal artery and renal vein hydrostatic pressures), divided by the total 
renal vascular resistance. It is expressed as follows: Note: Renal blood flow = Renal plasma flow/ 1- Hematocrit 635 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 7: What is the normal renal filtration fraction?
questions.explanation:
Normal renal filtration fraction (i.e. the fraction of renal plasma flow that is filtered) averages 
about 0.2. It means that 20% of the plasma flowing through the kidney is filtered through the glomerular 
capillaries. The remaining 80% leaves the glomerular capillaries by the efferent arterioles and 
becomes the peritubular capillary circulation. It is calculated by the given equation: When there is a fall in systemic blood pressure, the GFR falls less than the RPF because of 
efferent arteriolar constriction, and consequently, the filtration fraction rises.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following does not form filtration barrier?
questions.explanation:
Mesangium does not form a filtration barrier. It is made up of mesangial cells, supporting 
glomerular capillaries. The filtration barrier consists of: • Endothelium of the capillary • Basement membrane: • Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen • Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge • Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge • Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement 
membrane 636 
Sold by @itachibot A. The endothelial cells of the glomerulus; 1. Pore (fenestra) B. Glomerular basement membrane: 1. Lamina rara interna 2. Lamina densa 3. Lamina rara 
externa C. Podocytes: 1. Enzymatic and structural protein 2. Filtration slit 3. Diaphragm.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 9: Two particles share the same diameter. The one which will pass through the glomerular 
membrane has

options.d: Filtration across GBM does not depend on charge

questions.explanation:
For any given molecular radius, positively charged molecules are filtered much more readily than 
are negatively charged molecules. This is because the sialoproteins in the glomerular capillary wall are negatively charged, and this 
negative charge repels the negatively charged substances in the blood. Studies have showed that for tracer molecules presumed to be of similar size, charges which are 
filtered are positive charge > neutral charge > negative charge.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 10: What size of neutral substances are permitted by the filtration barriers?
questions.explanation:
Filtration barriers permit neutral substances that have the size of 4-8 nm. Neutral substances with diameters: • <4 nm - freely filtered • >8 nm - not filtered • Between 4-8 nm - the permeability is inversely proportional to the diameter Clinical correlation: • Genetically abnormal basement membranes: Alport’s syndrome ( 3 and  4 chains on the long 
arm of chromosome 2 involved in autosomal dominant and recessive pattern;  5 chain on X 637 
Sold by @itachibot chromosome involved in X-linked inheritance) • Autoimmune response to basement membrane collagen IV ( 3 NC1 
domain): Goodpasture’s syndrome
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus?
questions.explanation:
Glomerular mesangial cells are not a part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. Juxtaglomerular apparatus contains: • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle forms the macula 
densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response 
to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing 
flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, that secrete 
renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in 
turn, increases blood pressure. Note: The distal convoluted tubule starts at the macula densa.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 12: In patients with renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear in the urine. What is the reason 
behind this?
questions.explanation:
In renal diseases, albumin is the first to appear because of its effective molecular diameter. In minimal change nephropathy, the negative charges on the basement membrane are lost even 
before there are noticeable changes in kidney histology. As a result of this loss of negative charges 
on the basement membranes, some of the lower molecular weight proteins, especially albumin 
(effective molecular diameter of 7 nm), are filtered and appear in the urine, a condition known as 638 
Sold by @itachibot proteinuria or albuminuria.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 13: Calculate the net filtration pressure across the GBM for a patient with Glomerular 
ultrafiltration coefficient = 6 Glomerular hydrostatic pressure =45 Glomerular capillary 
oncotic pressure =20 Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure =10 Bowman’s capsule oncotic 
pressure =0
questions.explanation:
Net filtration pressure = Hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries - Pressure in Bowman's 
capsule - Oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries. Net filtration pressure= [PG -PB- G+ B] Therefore, Net filtration pressure 
= (45-10-20+0) = 25-10 = 15 mmHg Note: Here, just the net filtration pressure is asked and not the GFR. GFR= Kf [PG -PB- G+ B]
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 14: How much is the inulin clearance?
questions.explanation:
Inulin clearance is equal to 125 ml/ min. Since it is used for the measurement of GFR, inulin 
clearance will be equal to GFR, i.e 125 ml/min Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit 
time. A higher renal clearance suggests the substance may be cleared almost completely in one pass 
through the kidneys while a low value describes a substance that may not be eliminated by the 
kidneys at all. Clearance refers to the volume of plasma that would be necessary to supply the amount of 
substance excreted in the urine per unit of time. Stated mathematically, Cx. Px = Ux. V where Cx is the clearance rate of a substance x Px is the plasma concentration of x Ux is the urine concentration of that x V is the urine flow rate Rearranging this equation, clearance can be expressed as 639 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 15: In a patient, urine flow rate is 10 mL/min; plasma inulin is 2 mg/mL; and urine inulin is 25 
mg/mL. Which of the following is true assuming GFR to be normal?
questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, inulin clearance = GFR. Inulin clearance is calculated by the formula: Substituting the values given, • Uinulin= 25 mg/mL • Vinulin= 10 mL/min • Pinulin=2 mg/mL 640 
Sold by @itachibot Thus, Inulin clearance=GFR (normal GFR= 125 ml/min) Inulin is a polymer of fructose, clearance of inulin can be used for measurement of GFR, because 
of the following reasons: • Freely filtered • Neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules • Nontoxic • Not metabolized by the body
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 16: 625 
Sold by @itachibot A patient's urine flow rate is 2 ml/min. What is the clearance of a substance x whose plasma 
concentration is 10mg/mL and in urine is 100mg/mL?
questions.explanation:
The clearance in the given scenario is 20 ml/ min. 641 
Sold by @itachibot C = Clearance (mL/min) [U]x = Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL)=100mg/mL V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min)=2mL/min [P]x = Plasma concentration of substance x (mg/mL)=10mg/mL Substituting the values,
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 17: What is the effect of sympathetic stimulation on GFR?
questions.explanation:
GFR decreases with sympathetic stimulation as there is afferent arteriolar constriction. Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves constrict the afferent and efferent renal 
arterioles through the  1 receptors. As the afferent areterioles have far more  1 receptors than the 
efferent, it results in decreased renal blood flow and GFR. 642 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 18: If a patient is on a high protein diet, what will be the effect on the GFR?
questions.explanation:
High protein intake increases GFR. Note: Increase in the plasma protein concentration is not the same as high protein intake. An 
increase in the plasma protein concentration decreases GFR due to a raised oncotic pressure. A 
high protein intake raises the amino acid concentration in the blood, not the plasma protein 
concentration.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following would cause an increase in both GFR and RPF?
questions.explanation:
Dilation of the afferent arteriole will increase both GFR and RPF. • Increase renal plasma flow (RPF) - because renal vascular resistance is decreased • Increase glomerular filtration rate (GFR) - because glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure is 
increased. • Filtration fraction (FF) remains normal Dilation of the efferent arteriole will increase RPF but decrease GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 20: 626 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following causes relaxation of the mesangial cells?
questions.explanation:
cAMP causes relaxation of the mesangial cells. The other agents mentioned in the options cause 
contraction of the mesangial cells. Agents causing relaxation of mesangial cells (mnemonic - DAnCE) 643 
Sold by @itachibot • Dopamine • ANP • cAMP • PGE2 Angiotensin II is an important regulator of mesangial contraction, and there are angiotensin II 
receptors in the glomeruli.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 21: What is the effect of prostaglandins on renal blood flow?

options.a: Increase blood flow to cortex and medulla
options.b: Increase blood flow to cortex and decrease blood flow to medulla
options.c: Decrease blood flow to cortex and increase blood flow to medulla
options.d: Decrease blood flow to cortex as well as medulla

questions.explanation:
Prostaglandins increase blood flow in the renal cortex and decrease blood flow in the renal 
medulla. PGE2 is partially responsible for the vasodilatation of the afferent arteriole, which increases blood 
flow to the glomerulus. This phenomenon describes why NSAIDs (which inhibit prostaglandin 
synthesis) result in afferent arteriole vasoconstriction. It can cause a reduced GFR in patients who 
rely heavily on prostaglandin synthesis to maintain renal blood flow.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 22: Which part of the proximal tubule is most susceptible to ischemic injury?
questions.explanation:
Regions of the kidney most prone to ischemic injury are the S3 segment of the proximal tubule 
and the medullary thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle (mTAL). These tubular areas exist 
physiologically in relatively lower oxygen conditions. The S3 segment, in particular, has a much lower capability of producing energy through glycolysis 
under anaerobic conditions than the mTAL. Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments: • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule 644 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 23: What is the effective renal plasma flow?
questions.explanation:
In humans, the effective renal plasma flow (eRPF) averages about 625 mL/min. Measurement of renal plasma flow (RPF) is done by measuring the clearance of 
para-aminohippuric acid (PAH). PAH is filtered and secreted by the renal tubules, hence it it can 
be used for RPF measurement. where: • RPF = renal plasma flow (mL/min or mL/24 hour) • CPAH = clearance of PAH (mL/min or mL/24 hourr) • UPAH = urine concentration of PAH (mg/mL) 645 
Sold by @itachibot • V = urine flow rate (mL/min or mL/24 hour) • PPAH = plasma concentration of PAH (mg/mL) Note: Renal blood flow= Renal plasma flow/ 1- Hematocrit
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following formulae is correct? 627 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
True renal plasma flow (RPF) is obtained by dividing effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) by 
extraction ratio. When we inject para-aminohippuric acid, 90% of it is filtered through the glomerulus at the rate 
of 625mL per minute - which is the effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). Using that, to we calculate 
the true RPF, we divide it by the extraction ratio to account for the 10% that is not filtered by 
dividing the ERPF by 0.9, hence getting the final value of ~ 700mL per minute When peripheral venous plasma concentration of PAH is used for calculation of RPF, RPF 
obtained is called effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). This is because PAH concentration is 
essentially identical to that in the arterial plasma reaching the kidney.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 25: In a patient with renal disease, you want to measure the filtration fraction. Which of the 
following substances will you use?
questions.explanation:
Inulin and PAHA are used to determine the filtration fraction. The filtration fraction is the ratio of 
GFR and RPF Inulin, a polymer of fructose can be used to measure GFR. Para-aminohippuric acid (PAHA) is 
used to measure RPF.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 26: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in 
response to stretch-induced by
questions.explanation:
646 
Sold by @itachibot The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by the opening of calcium channels. 
The mechanism is called myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular 
fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the 
vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular 
resistance. This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced 
injury. Autoregulation has two main mechanisms: • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g. 
prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+ • Myogenic mechanism
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 27: Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of

options.a: Increased Na + concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
options.b: Increased Cl - concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
options.c: Increased Na + concentration in macula densa
options.d: Increased Cl- concentration in macula densa

questions.explanation:
Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of increased Na+ concentration in macula 
densa. Macula densa are the specialized cells present at the distal end of the thick ascending loop of 
Henle where it reaches the glomerulus. Distal convoluted tubule starts from macula densa. 
Macula forms part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus. While both Na+ and Cl- are delivered to the macula densa cells, it is the increased concentration 
of Na+ in the cells that increases the Na+-K ATPase activity leading to the feedback. 647 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 28: Renal autoregulation is absent in which of the following cases? 628 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Renal autoregulation is absent in case of paralysis of vascular smooth muscle. Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles abolishes its action i.e., autoregulation of renal blood flow 
and GFR. Vascular smooth muscles act through myogenic mechanism of renal 
autoregulation. Paralysis of vascular smooth muscles can be brought about by administration of 
drugs. Renal autoregulation is present in denervated and in isolated, perfused kidneys. Feedback mechanisms intrinsic to the kidneys keep the renal blood flow and GFR relatively 
constant, despite marked changes in arterial blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and 
renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation. 648 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 29: Kidney responds to shock by  
.
questions.explanation:
Kidney responds to shock by increasing afferent arteriolar resistance. During shock, both afferent and efferent arterioles in kidney are constricted, however, the efferent 
vessels are constricted much more. The glomerular filtration rate and the plasma renal flow is decreased during shock. As plasma 
renal flow is decreased to a greater extent, the filtration fraction increases. (Option 1 & 3)
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 30: What is the function of tubuloglomerular feedback?
questions.explanation:
Tubuloglomerular feedback regulates glomerular filtration rate (GFR). As the rate of ■ow through the ascending limb of the loop of Henle and first part of the distal 
tubule increases, glomerular filtration in the same nephron decreases, and, conversely, a decrease 
in ■ow increases the GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 31: The concentration of a substance is 2 mg % in afferent arteriole and 0 mg% in the efferent 
arteriole of a patient. This substance is
questions.explanation:
A concentration of 0 mg% is efferent arteriole indicates the substance is freely filtered. Afferent arterioles  glomerulus (filtration)  efferent arterioles  peritubular capillaries 
(reabsorption+secretion). Note: The question compares the concentration in afferent and efferent arterioles. Reabsorption 
and secretion happen between the tubular lumen of the nephron and the peritubular capillaries 
and not the efferent arteriole.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 32: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent 
filtration is? 629 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is 
heparan sulfate. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins. Collagen type IV, fibronectin, entactin are structural components of basement membrane.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 33: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except:

options.c: Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
options.d: Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.explanation:
Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries. Efferent arteriolar constriction has a biphasic response on GFR depending on the severity of 
resistance. 649 
Sold by @itachibot Moderate efferent arteriolar constriction causes increased glomerular hydrostatic pressure and 
slightly increased GFR. However, in cases of severe efferent arteriolar constriction (more than threefold increase in 
efferent arteriolar resistance), the renal blood flow is significantly reduced. This results in 
increased plasma protein concentration, thereby increasing the glomerular colloid oncotic 
pressure. As the increase in colloid oncotic pressure exceeds the increase in hydrostatic pressure, 
the net force for filtration decreases, resulting in decreased GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question: Question 34: GFR is increased by all except
questions.explanation:
Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Following ureteral obstruction, there is a progressive fall in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) due to 
a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of 
filtering nephrons. All the other factors/options increase GFR.
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a

questions.question:
Question 35: This is the graph depicting the filterability of dextran through the kidney, 1 representing 
complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Choose the substance A, B, C 
respectively. 630 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Glucose is completely reabsorbed in DCT.
options.d: PAH at any plasma concentration is completely filtered and secreted.

questions.explanation:
In the given graph, the order of filterability is A>B>C, which likely indicates that the 
substances are Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic. The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative 
charged (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered. Hence, the order of filterability would be: Polycationic > Neutral > Polyanionic, represented 
by A, B, and C in the graph shown. The glomerular filtration barrier consists of: 650 
Sold by @itachibot • Endothelium of the capillary • Basement membrane: • Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen • Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge • Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge • Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement 
membrane The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which 
measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less 
than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches 
zero. However, in addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge 
of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged 
proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The 
property can be studied by using charged dextran. When the filtration of the negatively and positively charged dextrans was studied, the results 
indicated that the negatively charged dextrans in the blood are repelled, with the result that 
filtration of anionic substances 4 nm in diameter is less than half that of neutral substances of the 
same size. This explains, why albumin despite having an effective molecular diameter of approximately 7 
nm, has a very low filtration rate. 651 
Sold by @itachibot Renal Tubular Functions, Urine Concentration and Dilution
questions.chapter_heading: Glomerular Filtration Rate  Renal Blood Flow  a
